questiontext.text:
In a grocery store, you push a 14 kg shopping trolley with a force, P, of 35 N. Its wheels offer a resistive frictional force of 20 N (as shown in the diagram below).

If the shopping trolley starts at rest, how far does it move in 7 seconds?

{1:NUMERICAL:=26.3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)



(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
The resultant force acting on the trolley is equal to:

$$P-20=35-20=15N$$.


Newton's second law states that,

"A force applied to a body causes an acceleration of that body of a magnitude proportional to the force, in the direction of the force, and inversely proportional to the body's mass."

This can be written algebraically as $$F=m\cdot a$$

Applying it to this situation,

$$a=(F/m)=(15/14)=1.1$$ m/s2

Then applying one of the equations of motion: $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$,

$$s=\frac{1}{2}\times1.1\times7^2=26.3$$ metres

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://a.files.bbci.co.uk/bam/live/content/zrshyrd/large'

hint.text:
HINT

First calculate the resultant force acting on the trolley, then apply Newton's second law of motion.

In a grocery store, you push a 18 kg shopping trolley with a force, P, of 31 N. Its wheels offer a resistive frictional force of 20 N (as shown in the diagram below).

If the shopping trolley starts at rest, how far does it move in 4 seconds?

{1:NUMERICAL:=4.9:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)



(Question ID #22).

generalfeedback.text:
The resultant force acting on the trolley is equal to:

$$P-20=31-20=11N$$.


Newton's second law states that,

"A force applied to a body causes an acceleration of that body of a magnitude proportional to the force, in the direction of the force, and inversely proportional to the body's mass."

This can be written algebraically as $$F=m\cdot a$$

Applying it to this situation,

$$a=(F/m)=(11/18)=0.6$$ m/s2

Then applying one of the equations of motion: $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$,

$$s=\frac{1}{2}\times0.6\times4^2=4.9$$ metres

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In a grocery store, you push a 11 kg shopping trolley with a force, P, of 33 N. Its wheels offer a resistive frictional force of 20 N (as shown in the diagram below).

If the shopping trolley starts at rest, how far does it move in 7 seconds?

{1:NUMERICAL:=29:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)



(Question ID #43).

generalfeedback.text:
The resultant force acting on the trolley is equal to:

$$P-20=33-20=13N$$.


Newton's second law states that,

"A force applied to a body causes an acceleration of that body of a magnitude proportional to the force, in the direction of the force, and inversely proportional to the body's mass."

This can be written algebraically as $$F=m\cdot a$$

Applying it to this situation,

$$a=(F/m)=(13/11)=1.2$$ m/s2

Then applying one of the equations of motion: $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$,

$$s=\frac{1}{2}\times1.2\times7^2=29$$ metres

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In a grocery store, you push a 20 kg shopping trolley with a force, P, of 33 N. Its wheels offer a resistive frictional force of 20 N (as shown in the diagram below).

If the shopping trolley starts at rest, how far does it move in 5 seconds?

{1:NUMERICAL:=8.1:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)



(Question ID #64).

generalfeedback.text:
The resultant force acting on the trolley is equal to:

$$P-20=33-20=13N$$.


Newton's second law states that,

"A force applied to a body causes an acceleration of that body of a magnitude proportional to the force, in the direction of the force, and inversely proportional to the body's mass."

This can be written algebraically as $$F=m\cdot a$$

Applying it to this situation,

$$a=(F/m)=(13/20)=0.7$$ m/s2

Then applying one of the equations of motion: $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$,

$$s=\frac{1}{2}\times0.7\times5^2=8.1$$ metres

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In a grocery store, you push a 17 kg shopping trolley with a force, P, of 33 N. Its wheels offer a resistive frictional force of 20 N (as shown in the diagram below).

If the shopping trolley starts at rest, how far does it move in 6 seconds?

{1:NUMERICAL:=13.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)



(Question ID #85).

generalfeedback.text:
The resultant force acting on the trolley is equal to:

$$P-20=33-20=13N$$.


Newton's second law states that,

"A force applied to a body causes an acceleration of that body of a magnitude proportional to the force, in the direction of the force, and inversely proportional to the body's mass."

This can be written algebraically as $$F=m\cdot a$$

Applying it to this situation,

$$a=(F/m)=(13/17)=0.8$$ m/s2

Then applying one of the equations of motion: $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$,

$$s=\frac{1}{2}\times0.8\times6^2=13.8$$ metres

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
